source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: The Type II starting material was $1 3 0 \mathrm { - m m }$ double vacuum arc melted ingots of approximately $1 0 { \cdot } \mathbf { k } \mathbf { g }$ as-cast weight

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: These ingots were all beta-forged to a slab thickness of approximately $3 8 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ and were then beta-quenched

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: The Type II material was beta-quenched into a $3 0 \%$ solution of polyethylene glycol in order to produce a $2 \ : \mathrm { K } / \mathsf { s }$ cooling rate

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: The Type I and Type III materials were quenched directly into water. The cooling rate for this treatment was estimated as about $2 5 \ \mathrm { K } / \mathsf { s }$

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: Following beta-quenching, the Type I slabs were preheated to $7 8 0 \mathrm { { ‰} }$ and hot rolled to 6 mm thickness

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk1
evidence_span: the Type II slabs were hot rolled to $3 \ \mathrm { m m }$ thickness at the same temperature

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk1
